section.title: Removing a VSA Node

para.para: Removing a VSA node allows you to remove capacity.

section.para: The process for removing VSA nodes from your cloud environment involves two major steps:

listitem.para: Removing the VSA node(s) from your input model
Updating your VSA management group and cluster to remove the node(s)

section.para: Once you have completed the removal of your VSA node(s) you will also want to remove those hosts from your monitoring checks and we show how to do that as well.

sidebar.title: Notes
sidebar.para: While removing VSA storage system permanently, the operator needs to ensure there is an odd number of managers running to avoid split brain syndrome. For example, if there are five nodes and one node is getting removed the operator needs to stop the manager running on any of the remaining four nodes.

sidebar.title: How to remove a VSA node from your management group and cluster
sidebar.para: You can remove VSA node(s) in an automated process using the provided Ansible playbooks (using the instructions) only if you had used the Ansible playbook method initially to create the cluster. If you used the HPE StoreVirtual Centralized Management Console (CMC) GUI to create the cluster, you must continue to use the CMC utility to remove node(s) and manage your cluster.
If you created the VSA cluster using Ansible playbook, you can remove VSA from that cluster using the same playbook.

sidebar.para: Show | Hide Using the CMC Utility

listitem.para: Launch the CMC utility. You will likely want to use the same method you used when you did your initial VSA cluster configuration. See for more details.
[OPTIONAL] If manager is running on the VSA node you want to remove from the cluster then you have to first stop manager.

To stop manager, right-click on the VSA node and select Stop Manager. It will give a pop-up warning stating "Are you sure you want to stop the manager running on ..". Go ahead and click OK to stop manager. Start a manager on a different VSA node where manager is not already running to maintain quorum and the best fault tolerance, if necessary. To start manager, Right click on VSA node and select Start Manager. Please ensure there is an odd number of managers running to avoid split brain syndrome.

In the Remove Storage Systems from Cluster window, select the specific storage system from the list and click OK:

Select a system to remove from the management group and click Remove from Management Group:
It will ask for confirmation. Click OK:
After successful removal of the VSA node, it will be available under the Available Systems list:

sidebar.title: How to remove a VSA node from your monitoring checks
sidebar.para: Once you have removed the VSA node from your cloud infrastructure, the Host Status alarm against it will trigger so there are additional steps to take to resolve this issue.

listitem.para: SSH to each of the Monasca API servers in your environment individually and do each of the following steps on them.
Edit the /etc/monasca/agent/conf.d/host_alive.yaml file to remove references to the VSA node you removed. This will require sudo access. The entries will look similar to the one below:
listitem.screen: - alive_test: ping built_by: HostAlive host_name: helion-cp1-vsa0001-mgmt name: helion-cp1-vsa0001-mgmt ping
